results.title: White manure
results.creator_credit: M. Bhavnani, Films Division, Government of India and Mohan Wadhwani
results.brief_description: Shows Sindri (India), which has the largest chemical fertilizer factory in Asia. The plan and the technical processes of the factory are shows, and tis significance for Indian agriculture is underlined.

results.title: White man's country
results.creator_credit: Anthony-David Productions, Films Incorporated, Anthony Howarth and David Kopp
results.brief_description: This is a well-documented film which deals with British Colonialism in Kenya from an African viewpoint. This film works as an expose of colonialists, and can be used to study them, or as part of an African history course.

results.title: White flood
results.brief_description: The film opens with a review of the forces that affect the surface of the earth - volcanic action, earthquakes, atmospheric conditions. A study of glaciers follows in which the life history of a glacier is examined from its birthplace in the mountains to the day when it floats into the sea.

results.title: White dust and lies
results.brief_description: A man lies dying in hospital. He is suffering from mesothelioma. His daughter, a trained nurse and filmmaker, searches in the past, present and future to find answers to the unanswered questions about his death. Her search uncovers the legal and moral issues raised by the link between exposure to asbestos and cancer and the ongoing fight for compensation for sufferers of asbestos related disease and government action to raise public awareness of the dangers of asbestos. Narrated by Jacqy Phillips. Produced with assistance from the Asbestos Diseases Foundation of NSW.

results.title: White clay and ochre
results.brief_description: Australian aboriginal cave paintings in ochre tell of their tribal life in western New South Wales. Finger, brush and stencil techniques are used to portray hunting kangaroos and emus, corroborees, magic and ritual maps. Special equipment is used by a field party to copy the paintings to scale for detailed scientific record and research. A cave-floor is carefully excavated to find implements used by the cave dwellers, and charcoal samples taken for dating tests. Music from “Namatjira” by Clive Douglas.

results.title: White blood cells: defense against disease
results.brief_description: Shows how the white blood cells capture the diseased organisms and destroy them. Special cells not only destroy bacteria, but are also capable of removing white blood cells that have been overcome in their battle with the invading organisms. Removal of invading organisms prevents them from multiplying and overwhelming the body defences. Shows the white blood cells in all the various work they do.

results.title: White Australia Policy
results.creator_credit: Student Action of Melbourne University and Unifed Productions
results.brief_description: A documentary record culled from television and other news reports on the White Australia Policy as it found expression in topical incidents in 1961, 1962 and 1963. It is a protest against the White Australia Policy and a record of the events in the history of Student Action. Compiled and edited by Peter Tammer. Dedicated to the memory of Bill Thomas, student leader.
